Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk procps-ng
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: procps-ng bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The procps-ng packages contain a set of system utilities that provide system information including ps, free, skill, pkill, pgrep, snice, tload, top, uptime, vmstat, w, watch, and pwdx. The procps-ng packages have been upgraded to upstream version 3.3.10, which provides a number of bug fixes and enhancements over the previous version, including: Previously, there was no way how to find the amount of free memory for starting new applications without swapping. This amount had to be estimated based on the values reported as Cached and Shmem. Such estimates were often incorrect, and this practice also reinforced a misconception that memory available in the page cache can be considered free. An updated Linux kernel now automatically estimates the amount of available memory that can be made free if needed. The updated procps-ng packages reflect this change and the estimation of available memory is now reported as a new 'available' field in the 'top' and 'free' utilities. This update also provides layout enhancements to both tools. (BZ#1070736) Previously, the 'w' tool did not display the FROM field by default like it is in the previous major versions of Red Hat Enterprise Linux and could only be enabled with the '-f' or the '-i' switch. With this update, the FROM field is printed by default and the '-f' switch disables the field. (BZ#1078310) Previously, the ps tool only displayed maximum 19 characters of user names even when the column width was set to a higher number. With this update, the procps-ng tools support up to 32 characters per user name. (BZ#1112734) This update removes an unnecessary explicit dependency of the procps-ng packages on the systemd-libs package. This change allows to move the required systemd libraries to different subpackages without breaking the dependencies. (BZ#1113206) This update introduces manual pages for the openproc(), readproc() and readproctab() functions in the procps-ng-devel subpackage and also provides fixes for the pgrep(1) and top(1) manual pages. (BZ#1119260, BZ#1119263) Under certain circumstances, the pgrep tool returned the 0 exit code even when there was a syntax error in the command. This bug has been fixed and pgrep now returns correct exit codes. (BZ#1116309) This update introduces the new 'q' option (alternatively '-q' or '--quick-pid') to the 'ps' command. This option processes only /proc/PID/ directories that are relevant to a user-specified list of PIDs in the order defined by the user. Therefore, it is a speed-optimized enhancement of the 'p' option. However, '-q' is mutually exclusive with other filtering options, so it is recommended in cases where users only need to specify a list of PIDs to be printed without further processing. (BZ#1060715) Users of procps-ng are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
